author: Jeff Parsons
title: Study reveals most people do this without realising after shaking someone's hand
text:
Next time you shake someone's hand , you will probably follow it up with a subconscious sniff, scientists believe.
Researchers in Isreal have uncovered a strange trait that links humans closely with other mammals: we still use scent as a means of identification .
According to a study carried out by a team at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Isreal, humans sniff their hands after shaking them with someone else.
The researchers believe it's a way of conveying vital information.
“We started looking at people and noticed that afterwards, the hand somehow inadvertently reached the face,” Noam Sobel, who led the team, told New Scientist .
As part of the study, Sobel's team secretly filmed 153 volunteers as they greeted them - some with and some without a handshake.
Getty
They recorded how often the volunteers put their hands to their nose for a sniff after the greeting.
The respondents were hooked up to physiological instruments measuring their airflow to make sure they weren't just scratching.
Sure enough, after shaking hands, the volunteers smelled their hands on average more than twice as much as when they didn't shake.
Strangely, the volunteers smelled their hands more after shaking them with a member of the same sex than with the opposite sex.
“People constantly have a hand at their face, they are sniffing it, and they modify that behaviour after shaking hands. That demonstrates that the handshaking is a chemosignalling behaviour,” said Sobel.
Getty
Other experts have agreed with the findings in Isreal.
“It fits with the general idea that there is a lot more chemical communication going on that we are unaware of," said Charles Wysocki at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia.
The results of the study appeared in the journal eLife .
Now the scientists say that the next step is to determine exactly what information we are transferring to each other with our scent.
